final_period_characterizations.topic_description: The 1966-1975 NLP paradigm centered on symbolic logic and rule-based parsing, as seen in Transition Network Grammars (1970) and On Context-Free Languages (1966), which emphasized formal grammatical structures and finite automata. representative_papers.title: Ways with Words

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: The 1998-2000 NLP paradigm combined statistical methods with symbolic logic, as seen in the multinomial model's superiority in text classification (1998) and the integration of WordNet with local context for word sense disambiguation (1998). representative_papers.title: A comparison of event models for naive bayes text classification
representative_papers.abstract:
The article compares two first-order probabilistic models used in naive Bayes text classification: the multi-variate Bernoulli model and the multinomial uni-gram language model. It clarifies their differences and empirically evaluates their performance across five corpora, revealing that the multinomial model generally outperforms the Bernoulli model, especially with larger vocabulary sizes, achieving an average error reduction of 27%.

Topic: computer science, text mining, natural language processing, machine learning, bayesian analysis, document classification, data science, machine learning research, automatic classification, event models, classification method

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: This paradigm, characterized by the integration of statistical models with symbolic logic and rule-based systems, dominated NLP research from 2002-2007. Meanwhile, works such as 'The architecture of the bilingual word recognition system: From identification to decision' (2002) and 'Introduction to the CoNLL-2002 Shared Task' (2002) highlight the continued reliance on symbolic logic and rule-based parsing for structured tasks like named entity recognition and bilingual processing.
